text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Subsections 1.4.9.1 through 1.4.9.9.8, References of “Review and Program Evaluation ”updated to“ Assurance and Advisory”
1.4.9.9.2 (1) (i), Removed, “keeping a record of original tax returns charged to the group; and maintaining controls and ﬁles”.
New subsection 1.4.9.9.2 (2) (f), Changed (Minimum of three reviews per year, two case reviews, and one workload review) to (Minimum of three case reviews per year and one workload review).
1.4.9.2.2.1 New subsection created, Duties of the Supervisory Investigative Analyst.

Subsection 1.4.9.4 (1), Changed “It is the responsibility of the SSA to ensure that their special agents work at developing signiﬁcant criminal investigations”, now reads; It is the responsibility of the SSA/SIA to ensure that their special agents and investigative staff work at developing signiﬁcant criminal investigations”.
Subsection 1.4.9.4 (7), Changed “Document Manager” to “Uniﬁed Checklist”.

Subsection 1.4.9.6.4 (1) (g), Deleted entire (1) (g) bullet “undercover/security cover agent; administrative duties including a review of Form 10411, Reimbursement Claim for Conﬁdential Expenditures on Official Business, cover documents inventory, stored documents, etc. This is handled by SIT.

Guide for Management Officials - Investigation 1.4.9
This section is intended to serve as a guide to assist Criminal Investigation (CI) management officials. The various topics in this section include:

Responsibilities Workload Selection and Assignments Management Responsibilities When Initiating Investigations Workload Reviews Review of Group Operations by the Special Agent in Charge Assistant Special Agent in Charge (ASAC) Review of Prosecution Recommendation Reports Assurance and Advisory (AA) Required Brieﬁngs Trauma Management for Supervisory Special Agents (SSA)
IRM
, Authority (Criminal Investigation) IRM Part
Chapter
, Servicewide Policies and Authorities IRM Part
Chapter
, Resource Guide For Managers IRM Part
Chapter
, Managing Statistics in a Balanced Measurement System
The table lists commonly used acronyms and their deﬁnitions:

Acronym Deﬁnition AA Assurance and Advisory ABP Annual Business Plan ADP Automated Data Processing AFC Asset Forfeiture Coordinator AO Administrative Officer ASAC Assistant Special Agent in Charge BSA Bank Secrecy Act CFR Code of Federal Regulations CI Criminal Investigation CI Conﬁdential Informant CIMIS Criminal Investigation Management Information System CIS Computer Investigative Specialist COPS Concerns of Police Survivors CSA Compliance Support Assistants CT Criminal Tax

CW Cooperating Witness DOJ Department of Justice EAP Employee Assistance Program EEO Equal Employment Opportunity FECA Federal Employees Compensation Act FEGLI Federal Employee Group Life Insurance GI General Investigation HQ Headquarters HR Human Resources IA Investigative Analyst IDP Individual Development Plan LEAP Law Enforcement Availability Pay LEM Law Enforcement Manual NCITA National Criminal Investigation Training Academy OPM Office of Personnel Management PFP Physical Fitness Program PI Primary Investigations PIO Public Information Officer SAC Special Agent in Charge SCI Subject Criminal Investigations SIA Supervisory Investigative Analyst SSA Supervisory Special Agents SSA Social Security Administration TFIA Tax Fraud Investigative Assistants TIGTA Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration TIMS Total Inventory Management System
and effective utilization of the CI workforce to accomplish the strategies and mission of IRS and CI. (

) The SSA/SIA is responsible for the efficient and effective performance of their assigned group and its assigned responsibilities. The primary responsibility of the group is to investigate signiﬁcant ﬁnancial crimes in accordance with estab- lished policies and programs.
Guide for Management Officials - Investigation 1.4.9
) The SAC and ASAC are responsible for the efficient and effective operation the assigned ﬁeld office. (

) The Director, Field Operations is responsible for the effective and efficient operation of their assigned area. The Director, Field Operations are of the Chief, CI’s executive staff and assist in the development of the annual business plan. (
) Directors who report to the Chief, CI, are responsible for their assigned of responsibilities. (
) The Chief and Deputy Chief, CI, are responsible for leading the organization achieving the CI mission, as well as the overall mission of the IRS. (
) Criminal Investigation special agents, , and CSA are under the direction of SSA. (
) Criminal Investigation investigative professional staff (TFIAs and IAs) are the direction of the SIA. (

) Supervisory Special Agents and Supervisory Investigative Analysts supervise employees in their assigned group and are under the direction of and report the SAC and/or the ASAC. In ﬁeld offices without an ASAC, the SSA/SIA directly to the SAC. In ﬁeld offices with an ASAC, the SSA/SIA will follow the chain of command and report ﬁrst to the ASAC. (

) Assistant Special Agents in Charge supervise SSAs/SIAs and are under the direction of the SAC. The ASAC may also supervise other personnel such the PIO, budget analyst, AO, management analyst, and intelligence analyst. (

) Special Agents in Charge, depending on the conﬁguration of the ﬁeld office supervise SSAs and/or ASACs. The SAC is under the direction of the Field Operations. The SAC may also supervise other personnel such as the PIO, budget analyst, AO, and management analyst. (
) Director, Field Operations supervises SACs and area office analysts. The Director, Field Operations is under the direction of the Chief, CI. (
) The Chief and Deputy Chief, CI, are under the direction of the IRS Deputy Commissioner. (

) The SSA plans and directs the group’s work by: a. Providing leadership in carrying out CI-HQ and ﬁeld office plans and programs b. Assigning investigations and other work and reviewing and the workload as necessary c. Directing senior employees to assist in planning and directing the work the other group employees d. Directing employees to plan, schedule, and perform activities within scope of their duties e. Keeping current with relevant legislation, court decisions, and f. Advising employees on policies, procedures, and investigative g. Reviewing completed investigative reports Internal Revenue Manual

) The SSA is responsible for a wide range of administrative and clerical These include, but are not limited to: a. Timely and accurate updating of the CIMIS database (within

days) TIMS. The accuracy and completeness of these databases is critical to the proper operation of the group, ﬁeld office, and HQ. b. Ensuring the proper and timely completion, submission and ﬁling of all monthly reports for all agents. c. Proper and timely completion of all annual certiﬁcations by all d. Ensuring that all employee diaries are complete and up-to-date. e. Timely completion of required tax return and equipment inventories. f. Timely completing and documenting of all workload and case reviews (Minimum of three case reviews per year and one workload review). It is recommended that the workload review be scheduled in conjunction with the employee’s mid-year evaluation. g. Timely and accurate submission of all ad hoc reports required by the office. h. Timely and accurate completion and submission of all other periodic reports pertaining to the group, such as consensual monitoring reports, and so forth, are properly completed and timely submitted. (

) The SSA will look to the SAC/ASAC for direction and guidance relative to op- erations. The SSA will keep the SAC/ASAC informed on all signiﬁcant developments, major activities, and problems within the group which may affect upper management. It is especially important that the SAC/ASAC diately be made aware of any issue that may come to the attention of the news media, other agencies or operating units, or anyone above the SAC in the chain of command. In particular, the SSA will advise the SAC/ASAC of signiﬁcant occurrence such as: a. Personnel problems b. Inquiries made by HQ or the Director, Field Operations’ staff c. Unusual request from the attorney for the government d. Signiﬁcant and/or sensitive investigations (

) The Director, Field Operations plans and directs the area office work by: a. Providing leadership in carrying out CI-HQ plans and programs. b. Keeping current with relevant legislation, court decisions, and c. Authorizing sensitive investigation (see IRM

) Criminal Tax Counsel will review all Title

and sensitive investigation pros- ecution recommendations, grand jury requests, requests to use special investigative techniques (e.g., consensual monitoring and undercover opera- tions), search warrant affidavits and related enforcement action review search warrant inventories and seizure warrant affidavits, and prepare law fact memoranda. (

) It is the SSA’s responsibility to develop and maintain a good working ship with attorneys for the government which includes the US Attorney’s and the DOJ. The US Attorney is the primary “customer” of CI, without which CI cannot function. The SSA, in coordination with the SAC and ASAC, will work together with the attorney for the government to determine the tive inventory of the group. The program goals of the IRS will be taken into consideration, as well as the willingness and ability of the US Attorney’s and DOJ to allocate resources to achieving these goals. (
) The SSA should be alert for: a. The need for additional help in grand jury investigations, trial and trial.

) .It is the responsibility of the SSA/SIA to ensure that their special agents and investigative staff work at developing signiﬁcant criminal investigations. gations come from a wide variety of sources. Investigations can be initiated from information obtained within the IRS when a revenue agent or revenue officer detects possible fraud. Information is also routinely received from the public, as well as from ongoing investigations underway by other law ment agencies or by the United States Attorney’s Office. (

) The SSA/SIA should encourage the special agents within the group to close relationships and regular contact with the US Attorney’s Office, other enforcement agencies, and the other operating divisions to increase the potential of generating quality, high proﬁle investigations. (

) The SSA is responsible for doing everything possible to support the compli- ance efforts of the other operating divisions. This is particularly important in area of fraud referrals. This includes timely evaluation of fraud referrals received from the other operating divisions (see IRM

, General, Primary and Subject Investigations). Criminal Investigation management will fraud awareness and referrals from the other operating divisions by: a. Speaking at group meetings and training classes. b. Inviting managers and agents from the other operating divisions to meetings to discuss ways of maintaining a high level of cooperation. c. Conducting a thorough, complete and professional evaluation of fraud referrals received from the other operating divisions. This includes ating the totality of the referral and not just the information listed on the referral form. d. As appropriate, preparing memoranda commending the referring agent for above average performance. e. Identifying badges of fraud and additional actions to be taken to sustain the fraud penalty. (

PIs. All sensitive SCIs are authorized the Director, Field Operations. If delegated the authority, the ASAC will authorize Title
SCIs. The SAC will authorize all other investigations. Note: Investigations of banks and brokers or dealers in securities referenced in CFR

Guide for Management Officials - Investigation 1.4.9

) Special agents will prepare the request to initiate an SCI according to the es- tablished policies and procedures. The SSA will review the request, and whether to forward the request for authorization, based on the following factors: a. The allegation(s) and the potential for criminal prosecution. b. The information and evidence developed by the special agent. c. The LEM guidelines and other local prosecutorial standards. d. Program goals and guidelines. e. The current ﬁeld office inventory. f. Ability to prove the allegations in light of potential weaknesses. g. Other prosecutorial considerations, such as venue, statute of age and health of subject, notoriety of subject, other agencies involved, etc. (
) If the SSA decides to forward a SCI initiation package, he/she or his/her designee, will review

% of the CIMIS input for accuracy, which will then entered into CIMIS as the initial accuracy review. Uniﬁed Checklist and/or workﬂows will be consulted for the most recent update on what documents must be included in the package that goes to the ASAC/SAC/Director, Field Operations. These documents will always include a memorandum explaining the allegations. The nature and extent of any additional documents required depends on whether the investigation is to be conducted administratively or under the auspices of a grand jury. Furthermore, it will depend upon whether is tax/non-tax, service initiated or attorney for the government initiated, or an expansion of an existing grand jury. (

) The SSA/SIA has an important responsibility in identifying, selecting, and assigning work within their assigned group. Factors to be considered: a. Complying with IRS guidelines. b. Identifying areas of willful noncompliance. c. Providing coverage in areas of noncompliance identiﬁed in the ABP IRS strategies. d. Selecting investigations which will positively impact on compliance and accordance with the LEM. e. Maintaining a balanced workload within the group (assuming it is not a specialty group). Maintaining a balanced workload involves with the SAC/ASAC to determine the proper proportion of group gations involving legal source income, illegal source income, narcotics and terrorism investigations. (

) Supervisory Special Agents and Supervisory Investigative Analyst will to match the type, level and complexity of the investigation with the ability of the assigned special agent. If this is not possible, the SSA/SIA will provide ditional supervision or assign a senior special agent to assist with the investigative planning and implementation. (

) Supervisory Special Agents and Supervisory Investigative Analyst will closely monitor all assignments to ensure timely completion. Although deadlines change due to a variety of circumstances, it is the responsibility of the SSA/ SIA to ensure that investigations do not lie dormant or become stagnant. It is also the responsibility of the SSA /SIA to ensure that time is not wasted on Internal Revenue Manual

Special agents will prepare the request to initiate an SCI according to the es- tablished policies and procedures. The SSA will review the request, and decide whether to forward the request for authorization, based on the following factors:

a. The allegation(s) and the potential for criminal prosecution. b. The information and evidence developed by the special agent. c. The LEM guidelines and other local prosecutorial standards. d. Program goals and guidelines. e. The current ﬁeld office inventory. f. Ability to prove the allegations in light of potential weaknesses. g. Other prosecutorial considerations, such as venue, statute of age and health of subject, notoriety of subject, other agencies involved, etc.
If the SSA decides to forward a SCI initiation package, he/she or his/her designee, will review

% of the CIMIS input for accuracy, which will then be entered into CIMIS as the initial accuracy review. Uniﬁed Checklist and/or workﬂows will be consulted for the most recent update on what documents must be included in the package that goes to the ASAC/SAC/Director, Field Operations. These documents will always include a memorandum explaining the allegations. The nature and extent of any additional documents required depends on whether the investigation is to be conducted administratively or under the auspices of a grand jury. Furthermore, it will depend upon whether it is tax/non-tax, service initiated or attorney for the government initiated, or an expansion of an existing grand jury.

If the SSA decides to forward a SCI initiation package, he/she or his/her designee, will review 100% of the CIMIS input for accuracy, which will then entered into CIMIS as the initial accuracy review. Uniﬁed Checklist and/or workﬂows will be consulted for the most recent update on what documents must be included in the package that goes to the ASAC/SAC/Director, Field Operations. These documents will always include a memorandum explaining the allegations. The nature and extent of any additional documents required depends on whether the investigation is to be conducted administratively or under the auspices of a grand jury. Furthermore, it will depend upon whether is tax/non-tax, service initiated or attorney for the government initiated, or an expansion of an existing grand jury.
The SSA/SIA has an important responsibility in identifying, selecting, and assigning work within their assigned group. Factors to be considered:

assigning work within their assigned group. Factors to be considered: a. Complying with IRS guidelines. b. Identifying areas of willful noncompliance. c. Providing coverage in areas of noncompliance identiﬁed in the ABP and IRS strategies. d. Selecting investigations which will positively impact on compliance and accordance with the LEM. e. Maintaining a balanced workload within the group (assuming it is not a specialty group). Maintaining a balanced workload involves coordination with the SAC/ASAC to determine the proper proportion of group investi

gations involving legal source income, illegal source income, narcotics and terrorism investigations. Supervisory Special Agents and Supervisory Investigative Analyst will attempt to match the type, level and complexity of the investigation with the ability of the assigned special agent. If this is not possible, the SSA/SIA will provide ditional supervision or assign a senior special agent to assist with the investigative planning and implementation. Supervisory Special Agents and Supervisory Investigative Analyst will closely monitor all assignments to ensure timely completion. Although deadlines change due to a variety of circumstances, it is the responsibility of the SSA/ SIA to ensure that investigations do not lie dormant or become stagnant. It is also the responsibility of the SSA /SIA to ensure that time is not wasted on Internal Revenue Manual

Resource Guide for necessary tasks. Each special agent should have an appropriate mix of investigations, information gathering and evaluative assignments. (

) Supervisory Special Agents and Supervisory Investigative Analyst must balance the importance of efficiently completing an investigation with responsibility to develop employees by challenging their ability. Employees usually best developed by providing increasingly complex assignments. (

) Three times per year the SSA will conduct case reviews of each agent’s inventory and completely and fully document them within CIMIS, utilizing Plan of Signiﬁcant Actions and SSA Case Load Review. The Plan of Actions and SSA Case Load Review must show the guidance and direction provided to the special agent. (

) The annual workload review will be conducted at the mid-year of the agent’s evaluation period . In addition to the areas covered in the case the workload review will cover administrative areas including the special agent’s diary, law enforcement availability pay, special agent development, government vehicle maintenance, returns inventory and controls, and gative equipment. The workload review will address the special agent’s performance. (

) The following areas, at a minimum, should be covered during each case review: a. Accuracy of the CIMIS and TIMS entries relating to the special investigations b. Violations being investigated c. Years being investigated d. Activities accomplished since last review e. Expectations to be accomplished before the next review f. Potential problems with the investigation g. CIMIS updates h. Estimated completion dates i. Date of last four-way conference (administrative investigations) j. Revenue agent involvement k. Statute of limitations, with special attention being paid to allowing time for the prosecution recommendation review process l. Elapsed time and time applied to the investigation m. Asset seizure and forfeiture potential (

) The following areas, at a minimum, should be reviewed on pipeline tions: a. Current location of investigations in the pipeline b. Narrative of last contact the special agent had with the assigned for the government c. Actions on investigation since last review d. Date anticipated for indictment, trial, sentencing, etc.

These reviews are performed by a team of senior analysts, MPAs, and other management personnel from ﬁeld offices outside the selected office under review. The areas of review include:

management personnel from ﬁeld offices outside the selected office review. The areas of review include: a. Leadership effectiveness b. Identiﬁed agency and investigative priorities c. day operations. ) Criminal Investigation will provide the appropriate response and support to special agents, special agent’s families and CI personnel following the for injury or death of a special agent while performing job related duties. (

) Criminal Investigation will provide liaison assistance to the immediate of any special agent who is critically injured or dies while performing job related duties (line-of-duty). Furthermore, a critical incident stress debrieﬁng coordinated by the EAP will be made available to all affected CI personnel (see IRM
, Personnel Matters). (
) Criminal Investigation will provide the appropriate response and support to special agents following the use of force by the special agent while job related duties. (
) This subsection contains procedures and responsibilities following critical or death of a special agent. (
) In the event of a critical injury or death of a special agent while performing related duties, CI will make notiﬁcation as designated by the special agent the Form
, Conﬁdential Line of Duty Notiﬁcation Information. The of the injured or deceased special agent must never be released before this notiﬁcation is made. (

) Notiﬁcation will be made in a timely manner (within one hour) by the SAC. the SAC is unable to make the notiﬁcation, he/she will designate the next highest ranking CI special agent to make notiﬁcation timely. If a CI special agent cannot make notiﬁcation timely, a local law enforcement agency will requested to make notiﬁcation. (
) If the SAC is unable to personally make notiﬁcation timely, he/she will the individual(s) to be notiﬁed in person, as soon as possible. (

) If there is an opportunity to get the individual(s) to be notiﬁed to the hospital prior to the death of the special agent, notiﬁcation will not be delayed to assemble the appropriate delegation. a. If the notiﬁed individual(s) requests to visit the hospital, he/she will be transported by someone from CI. Due to the possibility of shock, it is highly recommended that the notiﬁed individual(s) not drive the hospital. b. If young children are involved, CI will provide assistance to include ar- rangement for supervision of the children (as required). Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
H

) Notiﬁcation must always be made in person by two CI employees (SA, SSA, ASAC or SAC) and never alone. If the individual being notiﬁed has a problem, medical personnel should be available at the location at the time of notiﬁcation. (
) Notiﬁcation must never be made on the door step. The SAC or his/her, nated representative will ask to be admitted to the residence and ask the individual(s) to be seated prior to notiﬁcation. (

) Notiﬁcation will be made slowly, clearly, including all information currently available, and should never convey false hope. The special agent will be referred to by name and the words “died” and “dead” should be used than “passed away” or “gone”. (

) In the event a special agent is hospitalized with critical injuries sustained performing job related duties the special agent’s SSA, or designated tative, will: a. Coordinate with hospital personnel to provide appropriate waiting for family members and CI personnel (separate if possible). b. Establish a press staging area separate from waiting facilities for family members and CI personnel. c. Coordinate transportation for the family to and from the hospital. d. Coordinate with the hospital and HR to ensure that the medical bills related to the injured or deceased special agent are not sent to the special agent’s residence or family. e. Ensure the special agent’s family is promptly provided all available mation relating to the special agent’s condition. This includes providing speciﬁc information on how the special agent was injured, as well as allowing the family to spend time with the special agent, if possible. SSA should not be overly protective of the family. f. Notify the SAC of the current condition of the injured special agent and any changes in that condition. (

) In the event of a special agent’s death while performing job related duties, SSA, or designated representative, will: a. Notify the surviving family of the special agent’s desire to have or not have a law enforcement funeral as speciﬁed in the Conﬁdential Line of Duty Notiﬁcation Information form and provide all possible assistance with funeral arrangements, as requested. b. Coordinate reimbursement of funeral and burial expenses not to $
If the special agent resides within the United States and dies from his/her official duty station, an additional sum may be paid for portation of the remains to the official duty station city (
CFR

, Claims for Compensation Under the FECA). c. Issue a message to include name of deceased; date and time of circumstance surrounding the death; funeral arrangements (state if service will be private or a law enforcement funeral); detail regarding family’s request, if any, for expressions of sympathy in lieu of ﬂowers; and contact person and telephone number for additional information. d. Obtain an American ﬂag to be presented to the family. Internal Revenue Manual

) If criminal violations surround the critical injury, or death, of a special agent while performing job related duties, the SSA, or designated representative, a. Inform the special agent and/or the special agent’s family of all new velopments prior to press release. b. Keep the special agent and/or the special agent’s family apprised of and parole proceedings. c. Introduce the special agent and/or the special agent’s family to the assistance specialist of the court. d. Encourage the special agent and/or the special agent’s family, to the trial and accompany them whenever possible. e. Arrange for investigators to meet with the special agent and/or the special agent’s family at the earliest opportunity following the trial to answer all their questions. (

It is highly recommended this debrieﬁng occur within
hours of the incident. (

) If the special agent dies while enrolled in a self and family plan with a desig- nated Federal government health insurance provider, any family member covered by the plan is eligible for continued coverage. The survivor’s share the cost of the plan will be deducted from the annuity check (through the Federal Health Beneﬁts Program). However, once the insurance coverage is canceled, the coverage cannot be reinstated. Office of Personnel has the responsibility of determining the survivor annuitant status. (
) If the special agent dies while enrolled in the FEGLI, OPM will provide survivors with an application for beneﬁts. A certiﬁed copy of the death certiﬁ- cate should be attached to the application. (

) All uncashed annuity checks made payable to the deceased special agent must be returned to OPM. Government checks made payable to a deceased annuitant cannot legally be cashed by anyone. Office of Personnel Manage- ment will not authorize survivor beneﬁts until the Treasury Department them that there are no outstanding checks payable to the deceased special agent. If annuity payments are sent directly to a ﬁnancial institution, promptly notify OPM and the ﬁnancial institution of the special agent’s exact date of death. The Treasury Department will recover the amount from the depositor. Do not attempt to make individual repayment by personal check or money order to OPM or the Treasury Department. (
) In addition to the monthly beneﬁts the survivors receive, the deceased agent’s spouse is entitled to a one-time death payment of $
from the Security Administration. (
) The survivors of the special agent may be entitled to beneﬁts from state and local agencies (to be determined on a state by state basis). (

) In the event of critical injury or death of a special agent while performing job related duties, the SSA will coordinate with HR to provide the special agent the special agent’s beneﬁciary(ies) a report of the various beneﬁts available (including who to contact and when the payment can be expected). The SSA will meet with the special agent or the special agent’s beneﬁciary(ies) in ap- proximately six months to ensure the beneﬁts were, or will be received. (

) The Public Safety Officer’s Beneﬁt Act provides a one-time tax free beneﬁt to eligible survivors of a Federal law enforcement agent whose death is the and proximate result of a traumatic injury sustained in the line-of-duty. This beneﬁt is also provided for officers that have been permanently or totally disabled in the line of duty. As of October
, the death beneﬁt amount was $

) The responding SSA will: a. Ensure medical treatment is obtained as needed. b. Ensure the subject and the scene are secure. c. Contact local police, the TIGTA, and the SAC. d. Appoint a companion special agent for each involved special agent. e. In a shooting incident, place IRS ﬁrearms used in evidence with local police; obtain a receipt for the weapon. f. In the case of a special agent’s death or serious injury, ensure the agent’s spouse/family is notiﬁed; utilize Form
, Conﬁdential Line Duty Notiﬁcation Information. g. Send a copy of the Form
, Use of Force Incident Report to the NCITA. (

) The function of the special agent’s companion is to remain at the side of special agent involved in a traumatic incident. The special agent involved in the incident is probably experiencing varying degrees of stress. The companion special agent probably cannot do very much in relieving the but can help in handling it through the long periods of waiting and that may follow. The companion special agent and the involved special most likely will be feeling uncomfortable at this time, so the companion agent should relax and let conversation ﬂow naturally. (

) The companion special agent: a. Should not talk about speciﬁc details of the incident (i.e., when, why, etc.). b. Should not make congratulatory comments. c. Try to head off congratulatory type comments from other people. (

) It is okay for the companion special agent to: a. Talk about unrelated subjects. b. Empathize with the special agent and let him/her know you are trying share what he/she is going through. c. Talk about thoughts concerning the incident if the involved special wants to discuss them. The companion special agent may even encourage the special agent to talk about his/her thoughts at this time. The companion agent must remember that the special agent has a to his/her thoughts even if they are painful or make them feel able. (
) The companion special agent will not argue with the special agent involved the incident. (
) The companion special agent should try to let the special agent involved in incident do most of the talking. (

) Investigative imprest funds are set up as a vehicle for special agents of CI make expenditures of a conﬁdential nature. In some instances the imprest fund can be used for non-conﬁdential expenses where normal ment procedures cannot be used. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
H
The Investigative imprest fund is a negotiable instrument charged against a government appropriation account and advanced to a duly authorized cashier.
Guide for Management Officials - Investigation 1.4.9
The Director, Beckley Finance Center has the authority to establish the investi

gative imprest fund in ﬁeld offices upon determining that there is no other satisfactory means of providing funds essential to the enforcement of pertinent laws and regulations. For additional information on the investigative imprest fund see the Investigative Imprest Fund Overview for SSA posted in the e
library on the CI Web.
